PeusnerTalks On Architecture
Nikolaus Pevsner, distinguished European art historian, will
deliver the Albert and Gloria
Lion Lecture at Hopkins on
Sunday, November 21 at 4 p.m.
in Shrivel. Hall. Dr. Pevsner will
speak on "The Present State of
Architecture."
The annual memorial lecture,
established by the family of Albert and Gloria Lion, alternately brings to the Baltimore community distinguished speakers
from the social sciences and the
humanities. The inaugural lecture was presented last year by
Dr. Eric Goldman, special assistant to President Lyndon B.
Johnson.
After taking a Ph.D. in the History of Art
and Architecture, Dr. Pevsner served on the
staff of the Dresden Gallery and was successively
associated with the Universities of Leipzig,
Munich, Berlin, Frankfurt and Gottingen. While
a lecturer at Gottingen, he specialized in the
history of art in Great Britain.
Dr. Pevsner now resides in Hampstead, London
and is Professor of the History of Art at Birkbeck College, University of London. He was previously Slade Professor of Fine Art and a Fellow of St. Johns' College, Cambridge.
Since its inception, Dr. Pevsner has been the
editor of the Pelican History of Art and Archilecture; he has also written some twenty-five
volumes of The Buildings of England. He is a
member of the Editorial Board of The Archi-

NIKOLAUS PlEVSNER
tectural Review and is considered among the
most learned and stimulating contemporary
writers on art.
His book on Italian Painting of Mannerism
and Baroque is held as a standard work. Among
his other publications are An Outline of European Architecture, An Inquiry into Industrial
Art in England, German Baroque Sculpture, High
Victorian Design, and The Englishness of English
Art (Reith Lectures, 1955).
The lecture is open to the public without
charge.
Further information concerning the lecture
may be obtained from George S. Wills, Office
of Public Relations, Sluiver Hall, The Johns
Hopkins University, HO '7-3300. Ext. '704, 710.

Administration
Remains Quiet
By MEL SHUSTER
Charges of discrimination were
levelled at the Hopkins administration in a report issued
Wednesday by the Hopkins Committee for Basic Freedoms. The
study, which has been distributed
to all members of the administration, faculty, and graduate
student body, deals with an alleged University discriminatory
policy in matters of housing,
employment, and admissions.
After a series of inquiries by
a number of News-Letter personnel, the position of the administration toward the report appears to be' unqualified disapproval. Some administrators refuse to comment, while some
disclaim its content. In general,
there appears to be a question
of the legitimacy of the figures
and a disapproval of the committee's procedure in making public
the report. They seem to be inclined to ignore the report rather
than respond at this time.
Housing
Beginning
with
University
housing policy, the committee's
report attacks the administration for being lax in requiring
all commerical landlords renting to Hopkins students to pledge
not to discriminate, as it had
agreed to do in 1964.
In the succeeding paragraph
of recommendations, the report
cites such housing conditions as
a major deterrent to the attendance of non-white students at
Hopkins. The committee suggests
that "A public stand by the
University on this issue would
encourage more non-white students to come here, whereas
knowledge of current housing
conditions and the general lack
of concern about them would
tend to discourage their application."
Employment

Hopkins, the committee stated

Cellist Plays Jan. 9
Paul Olefsky, world renowned
American cellist, will appear in
concert at Hopkins on Sunday,
Jan. 9. The concert will be sponsored by the newly formed Hopkins chamber music group and
will feature music by the New
Chamber Orchestra under the direction of Angelo Gatto.
A review in the New York
Times noted that, "Unquestionably, Mr. Olefsky is one of the
finest cellists before\ the public
today." After winning the Naumberg Award and appearing at
Town Hall and on the Bell Telephone Hour, Olefsky became the
youngest solo cellist of the Philadelphia Orchestra. He has since
then won the Michaels Memorial
Music Award and conducted
chamber music festivals throughout the country.
Angelo Gatto is experienced as
a conductor, violinist, composer,

and teacher. He is a graduate of
Duquesne University and a
former student at Pittsburgh
Musical Institute, Columbia University. and the Berkshire Music
Center. Mr. Gatto is presently a
member of the Music Department
faculty at Morgan State College
In Baltimore. the Director of
Morgan Conununity Opera Theatre and Orchestra, and Director
of the Summer Youth Program
for the Peabody Conservatory.
The concert on January 9 will
begin at 8:30 in Shriver Hall.
Tickets may be obtained from
the Public Relations Office at
$1.50 for the public and $1.00
for students. The program will
include the world's first performance of Gatto's own "Veccht
Tempi" besides pieces by Leone
Sinigaglia, Antonio Vivaldi, Alfonzo Castoldi, and G. F. Handel.

Hal Draper, an editor of New
Politics magazine and a former
member of the steering committee of the Berkley Free Speech
Movement, will speak Tuesday,
November 25, at 4 p.m. in the
Garret Room of the L.Pisenhower
Library. His topic will be "The
New Radicalism and the Future
of the Left in America."
Draper's appearance is being
sponsored by both the Hopkins
and Goucher chapters of SDS.
Questions and discussion will
follow his presentation.
One of the founders of the
Independent Socialist Club at
Berkley, Draper became wellknown to thousands of students
throughout the nation with the
publication of his pamphlet "The
Mind of Clark Kerr." In this
pamphlet, he examined the role
of the university in contemporary American society concluding that institutions of higher
education have become "factories" in which students, starting out as "raw material" are
"processed and molded" to conform to the requirements of the
roles they are expected to play
In society upon graduation.
In addition to his most recent
activities of writing and speaking about the New Left, Draper
is the former editor of Labor
Action, the newspaper of the Independent Socialist League during the late 1940's and the 1950's.
Copies of "The Mind of Clark
Kerr" and "Berkley: The New
Student Revolt," His latest book,
will be available at the speech
on Tuesday.

Photo Exhibit
An exhibition of the photography of J. R. Schubel will open
at The Johns Hopkins University
on Thanksgiving Day, November
25. The thirty photographs to

I

be exhibited in the gallery of the
Milton S. Eisenhower Library
include both landscapes and pietorials.
Mr. Schubel, currently a graduate student in oceanography at
Johns Hopkins, has studied
photography under William Mortensen, the famous pictorial
photographer who died in August
1965. He has also studied at the
New York Institutes of Photography.
The exhibition will e opeil
daily through December 7.

Goucher Fast
542 valiant Goucher students
fasted yesterday to collect money
for poor Negroes in the South.
The Fast for Freedom was under
the direction of the National
Student Association (N.S.A.) and
was sponsored by the Goucher
Student Government,
The 542 starving girls signed
up earlier to forego their usual
evening repast. The Saga Food
Service, serving Gouc.her, will
compute the amount saved and
will turn over the money to the
N.S.A.
The N.S.A.intends to donate
the money to an organization in
the South for the use by poor
Negroes. "Not. only does the
money go to Mississippi, but to
other states as well," stated
Nancy Woodruff, student co-ordinator for the N.S.A. at Goucher. "The Poor Peoples Corporation
collects the funds, and they use
it for no interest loans to different groups of Negroes in the
South to start small businesses,"
she said.
Goucher student authorities
strenuously denied that the
project was also intended as a
mass dieting program, or as a
gambit to encourage Hopkins
students to take more Goucher
girls out to dinner.

Some Words To The Wise
We seldom generate enough conviction for an issue
to warrant warning the University administration that
their reaction to the issue if not well calculated, may have
far-reaching consequences.
The Wednesday publication on discriminatory practices at the University, submitted by the somewhat outspoken committee on Basic Freedoms is of such fundamental relevance to the policy of administration-student
relations, we are obligated to gather together, for the
administration, a few points of "student wisdom."
It is not necessarily or universally true that if one
doesn't scratch an itch, it will go away. But the officials
of the university are reluctant to admit otherwise:This
recent controversial publication is a thorn in the hide
of the administration; and we are convinced that the
best policy is not to deny any connection with the thorn,
or to privately "curse it out."
We have witnessed the truth of this, for example
by the fact that the flies who unmistakably prevail in
the Hutzler Reading Room of Gilman Hall do not respond to the shooing of them away. Nor do they respond
to the swat technique; these approaches merely add to
the persistence of their attack.
We've noticed, further of these flies, that for the
simple reason that the reading room is an inclosure
(comparable to the condition of the University as an
intellectual enclosure) a few of the flies suffocate. It
comes clear, in expanding this pertinent analogy, that
the number of the flies that do pass away are relatively
few proportional to the number who remain in force.
And it follows, consequently, that the tactic of protecting
an institutional enclosure such as the University from
discordant elements from the inside has only a limited
and often reverse effect.
Many students know, possibly because they have
been discordant elements (flies in the microcosmic
sense), that the hest way to get rid of discordant elements is to remove the cause around which they rally—
not the discordants themselves.

For the University macrocosm, this analogy says
the following things: that the four persons who have
published the report on discrimination have done so
because they honestly have discerned practices within
the University that are not compatible with their moral
convictions. Their inspiration can hardly be quelled by
silencing or by denying them official recognition. It
would be hest for concerned officials to combine efforts
with the disputants in order to discuss removal or clarification of the dispute; at any event, in order to allow
the issue to be "opened up" and the elements aired out.
We suggest, in conclusion, three steps of amelioration of this potentially explosive issue, based on policies
of inclusion rather than exclusion, of airing rather than
suffocation.
The administration should break the deadlock and
issue a report stating where they differ (in practice, not
necessarily in principle); we know of many creative attempts by the administration to attack these same issues.
The administration and the disputants might then have
grounds for conducting a public forum in which the
two groups could publically show some of the principles
they hold in common. And finally there is reason to
believe that a committee to take action on these common principles might evolve.

The old Rock and Roll—the rock and
roll of the fifties, Elvis Presley, Gene Vincent, the Platters had an appeal to a
rather narrow segment of the population,
but the New Rock and Roll as characterized by the writing and performing of the
Beatles and Bob Dylan has devleoped a
rather broad appeal. The audiences that
attend rock and roll concerts have beCome older and to a degree more sophisticated; the result of The New Rock and
Roll is an increased interest in rock and
roll among college students. Like folk music
In the early 1960's, Folk-rock or the New
Rock and Roll has become the staple
music of college students in the midsixties.
Unlike the music of the fifties most of
the New Rock and Roll is being composed
imaginatively, with greater freedom and
without the familiar cliches of the music
of the fifties. New chords, new progressions,
retrogressions and new subject matter

of Rhythm and Blues in the Early fifties—
it had its origins in the Negro and Country
music of the forties—the bebop, etc. The
first true rock and roll record recorded
by a white group was probably Crazy Man
Crazy, recorded by Bill Haley and The
Oomets,in 1951, but it was not until the

record was rereleased in 1954 that it began
to sell. In 1953, The Comets recorded Rock
Around the Clock, and this became the first
rock and roll record to make money. But
this record and the one that preceded it
were only isolated cases of rock and roll
and did not really usher in the movement.
It was a Negro group called the Chordes
that actually began the rock and roll cycle
with a recording of Sh-boom (later recorded for Mercury by the Crewcuts) in
1954. Record sales began increasing immediately in the rock field, but the first
reaction of the recording artists was to
copy the works of earlier Rhythm and
Blues singers such as Ivory Joe Tucker
and Big Bill Crudup). Emulating the style
of the earlier singers, however, the rock
and roll people began to develop their own
style—Elvis Presley, Jerry Lee Lewis, and
so on.
By 1957 it was easy to characterize most
of the rock and roll that was being recorded. The melody used the major progression (1-4-5-1), triplets were played
against a basic four-four time, and the
harmony was in triads. These predictable
elements soon tired all but the adolescent
listeners.
1958 marked the Introduction of folk
music into the rock and roll market with
the Kingston Trio's Tom Dooley. They appealed primarily to college students, sold
large numbers of albums, had a "good
act", collegiate look, and a new sound. It
seemed to be the logical refuge for the
listener tired by the familiar rock and
roll. Peter, Paul and Mary then flaunted
their image before the public, and it caught
on—among adolescent as well as the college crowds. Like the Kingston Trio, they
played much of the traditional folk music,
but soon began singing the songs Of new
song wrights—particularly Bob Dylan who
shares the same manager with Peter, Paul
and Mary (Al Grossman). Don't Think
Twice It's Alright, The Times They
Are A'Clianging and other Dylan
songs were presented to the public in a
style more readily accepted than Dylan's
own. Songs of a more contemplative mood
than normal found in the old rock and
roll were heard by the public (I parted the
weeds and looked over the swamp and
seen them natives doing the Ubangi Stomp
vs Dylans—When the rooster crows at the
break of dawn look out your window and
I'll be gone).

Honor The System
By THOMAS H. CARPENTER
Chairman,
The Honor Commission
When a freshman first arrives
at Hopkins, he is rushed through
endless orientation functions.
One of the half dozen assemblies
he attends is titled "The Honor
Assembly", and there he is told
that the Hopkins Honor System
is an important part of the undergraduate life, he is made
aware of the mechanical aspects
of the System, and he is deliberately explained his obligations under it. Then, throughout
the next four years, he is aware
of the System with each unproctored exam he takes and
with each News-Letter notification of a trial, but he is never
again reminded of his responsibilities. And although he may
graduate convinced that he has
been honorable in all of his academic pursuits, he may have only
partially fulfilled his obligations
to the preservation of the System
and with it the atmosphere of
trust and freedom from constant
observation that is so unique to
Hopkins.
Yearly, precocious freshmen
scoff at the possibility of an
Honor System and occasionally
an upper classman can be heard
to mumble that he is sure some
people cheat. Yet whether or not
the system works is wholly up
to the student body and each
student's obligation is not only

to be honorable in his academic,
pursuits, but also to turn in any
violations he may observe and
thus to protect the community
as a whole.
4 student may ask what the
phrase Honor System means,
wondering what a system of
honor can be. And the phrase
can have a pompous self-righteous air, but at Hopkins the
Honor System represents specific ideals defined through tradition. It embodies the accepted
means of pursuing academic
goals in the process of earning
a degree. Presumably the Bachelor's degree is the ultimate goal
of each student in the undergraduate body, and it is this one
factor that necessarily unites the
student body into a community
with a common purpose.
In idealistic terms, some students may be driven on by an
unquenchable thirst for knowledge, while many more are striving to be accredited in a profession and still others look for
the generally higher incomes of
Uncollege graduates.
fortunately the basis of the
structure of the degree is the
grade and again all students are
evaluated in terms of it.
The Honor System is concerned with the means a student uses
to earn his degree and thus to
earn his grades. In practical
terms, its purpose must be stated

The Johns Hopkins University
has announced the appointment
of Dr. John White, Pilkington
Professor of the History of Art
at the University of Manchester,
as Professor of Art at Homewood.
Dr. White, who will assume his
position at the beginning of the
academic year, succeeds the late

POETRY

Confession and Verse
• By JIM FREEDMAN
I found, in a New. Yorker of
late September, two lines of
verse, the words of an aging man
enjoying intimacy with a small
game announced on radio:
When I am told that the
hurler kicks, rocks and either
deals or delivers
I am again a tan cheeked boy
with no socks ....
Also in late September, there
was in progress the completion
of an anthology of 10 young
poets, all under 40 yrs., many of
them known well about this University, 6 of them present or
past graduate students in Elliot
Coleman's Seminar in Poetry.
Confessions and Experiments,
published by Linden Press, compiled by Robert Rosenburg, an
esteerned local poet and patron
of the arts, includes these lines
by Richard Kerschner, expressing a sentiment similar to the
above:
Shuffle through
my days and years of closets...
In an old overcoat I find
dated tickets, empty gloves:
dragon's teeth.
I remarked that the lines of
baseball remorse, by Baltimore
author Ogden Nash, pointed out,
by comparison with the lines
from Confessions and Experiments, written by a Hopkins
Senior, the value of this "September" book of poems.
These poems are young and
effectively display the diverse
pertness of youth; they are personal and intimate, as they were
chosen to be; and are very close
to home, by simple virtue of
propinquity.

While saying nothing' in particular 'about Ogden Nash, this
eoreParison.says a great deal in
favor of the .new anthology.
A Saturday Review 'article of a
few weeks passed lamented the
quality of this generation's creative writing. Its author stated
that students are "out to -picket"
rather than to conjure;'that the
distinguishing feature of the
contemporary, art form is that
it must involve both the audience
and the creator; that. as a consequence, student writing is essentially impersonal, apparently
lacking in confession and intitimacy. One critic quoted was
"depressed by how little experimentation or risk was to be
found anywhere.
We can only say, on reflection
of Confessions and Experiments,
that the Question-Title of the
Saturday Review article:. Where
Are All The Writers Gone?, can
Only be answered by saying that
the Saturday Review must have
gone with them.
The book can easily stand up
to such criticism of the age; for
its poems are, in truth, primarily
of experiments, and, without being too obvious, of confession.
"A poet writes to be believed"
is the aphorism prefacing the introduction. In this Introduction,
the editor Robert Rosenburg,
claims significantly that "poetry
is confession because it is the
most personal of all literary utterances. His claim is consistently born out by the frank expression of his chosen poets.

Recent Elections
By HOWARD J READ

What meaning does the recent
election have for the future of
American politics? After each
election this question is asked
by those who seek to divine the
political future by analysing the.
political past. The 1965 election
was no exception to this tendency. In fact, for an "off-year"
election the results were watched
with great care by all political
attention
pundits. Particular
was focused on New York City
where the, young, liberal, and
dynamic John Lindsay was out
to win city hall for a RepublicanLiberal coalition and oust the
Democrats who had been in
power since 1945. A new twist
was present in this election, however, for a group of far-right
Republicans under the label of
the Conservative Party sought
to punish Lindsay and his supporters for departing from what
the Conservatives considered to
be genuine Republican principles.
In other parts of the country
somewhat similar things were
happening. In Philadelphia a
former Democrat was running
for District Attorney as a Republican with ADA backing. He
was seeking to be the first citywide official not elected by the
Democrats since 1948. In Louisville a liberal Republican who
had supported public accommodations legislation was seeking
approval of his actions in his
race for mayor. All three of
these areas had been completely
turned off by Barry Goldwater's
candidacy and had returned
heavy Democratic
majorities
just a year before. But in 1965,
in all three areas and in several
other similar cases the Republican candidates were successful.

Theatre Hopkins Presents 'Milky Way'
"Do You Know the Milky
Way?", Karl Wittlinger's tragiccomedy of the post-war German
theatre, is scheduled to be presented at the Barn December 2,
through December 5 and December 9 through December 12.
Tickets are available at the
Office of Special Events in
Sluiver Hall.
The Theatre Hopkins production, under the direction of Edward J. Golden, Jr.. will be the
play's first performance in the
Baltimore area. Since 1957, the
play has been performed more
than 7,000 times in various countries, receiving an off-Broadway
production in March 1963.
Karl Wittlinger was born in
Karlsruhe, Germany, in 1922, the
only child of a cabinetmaker.
During the War he was wounded

and held prisoner by the American Army. His first contact with
the American theatre came after
the War while working on an
American Army production of
"Our Town." Later he handled
several odd jobs while studying
for a Ph.D. in philosophy. In
1953 he decided to dedicate himself solely to the theatre.

period. The hero of his play is
a mature man who retains the
imaginatior, and innocence of a
child in a world of cruelty and
indifference. He returns after
having been cut off from the
world of reality, giving the play
its dramatic and shocking effect.

Wittlinger's third play, "Do
You Know the Milky Way?" was
originally written for twenty
characters appearing in fourteen
scenes. However, it later became
clear that he could better express
his thoughts by having his hero
face only one person, the Doctor,
who could represent all the
others in his life. By casting his
hero as a returning soldier he
was able to achieve continuity
with the German post-war

Both Arthur Lopis, as the Man,
and Irvin Turner, as the Doctor,
had roles in "The Killer" which
opened the Theatre Hopkins season. The production played to
capacity audiences and was
scheduled for extra performances.

this way. Yet the benefits that
result from the atmosphere of
trust and freedom that it allows
to exist go far beyond this superficial level. Aside from the trust
'placed in him when an instructor leaves a room during an examination, a student is often allowed to take an examination to
his room, or to take it at a
more convenient time, and this
trust spreads into innumerable
areas. Also, when a student is
suspected of violating the system, he is tried by uninvolved
peers, rather than being immediately condemned by an engaged
Instructor, and if he is found
guilty he is given a constitutionally defined penalty.
The Honor Commission is the
mechanical aspect of the System
and functions only through the
support of the community. It
does not police or search for violation.s, and the trial procedure
only comes about when a suspected violation is reported to
the Commission. The Honor
Commission uses the concept of
unfair advantage as the general
definition of an honor violation,

while in addition, an instructor
may define other specific actions
which he considers violations in
his course. The Honor Commission is not a board devised to
judge the moral fibre of an individual, nor is an individual
judged as having offended any
God-given morals. A violator of
the Honor System, found guilty
by the Commission, is found
guilty of injuring the community. He has used unacceptable
means in his academic pursuits.
These means are not defined as
acceptable or unacceptable according to any omnipotent moral
code, but rather according to
means which are defined through
tradition within the university,
degree-seeking community as
honorable. "A student's use of
unacknowledged material other
than his own" is one large aspect
of what is considered under the
phrase unfair advantage, and
this coupled with "the use of
deceit" nearly completes the definition. These very simply are
dishonorable means, not intuitively dishonorable, but defined
as dishonorable in this highly
specific community.

An applicant to the university
signs a box on his application
form, agreeing to live under the
Honor System and he is not accepted into the university unless
he signs this box. The system
cannot be partially accepted,
but the entire student body must
support it, and the penalties for
violations are directed toward
Yet a.s the
this goal.
System cannot exist without the

community, the community as a
whole has the right to choose
whether or not to live under it.
But the choice open to the community is not whether or not to
live according to the means
established as honorable, but
rather the choice is, how these
means are to be imposed.

The Honor System is tangibly
concerned with the maintenance of the accepted structure
for attaining the Bachelor's degree, while at the same time, it
allows an atmosphere of trust
and self respect to exist. Yet the
System must not exist unless
the student body is willing to accept it and dynamically support
it without exception.

The Reading Room of the
original Gilman Hall Library
has been named in honor of the
late Mr. Albert D. Hutzler, Baltimore merchant and philantropist who served his city in the
tradition of Enoch Pratt, George
Peabody, and Johns Hopkins.
By action of the University's
Board of Trustees, the "Albert
D. Hutzler Undergraduate Reading Room" was created to honor
a University alumnus, trustee,
and past president of the Friends
of the Library.
The Hutzler Reading Room,
which serves as a focal point of
Gilman Hall, has long been
known for its scholarly atmosphere and its stained glass windows depicting the "marks" or
signatures of fifteenth century
printers.
Mr. John Berthel, University
librarian, said: "It is most appropriate that this undergraduate
facility be named for Mr. Hutzler
because he was a great friend
of Hopkins students and the
library program at the University."
Hutzler Honored
Mr. Hutzler was honored a
year ago at ceremonies opening
the new library at Hopkins,
which has subsequently been
designated the Milton S. Eisenhower Library, At that time, he
was presented with a bound volume of the "Ex Libris" periodicals published by the Friends of
the Library from 1931 to 1964.
The presentation marked one of
Mr. Hutzler's last official appearances at the University
prior to his death in June, 1965.
Mr. Hutzler's philosophy concerning the library program at
Johns Hopkins was appropriately
expressed in his remarks at the
1964 ceremonies. At that time,
he said: "It is not primarily the
building that gives us pride, it
is rather that this library will
provide vastly improved services
to the students -and faculty of
the University. It is for this reason, above all others that those
of us involved in the library's
planning found pleasure and
excitement in the work. This is
one of the most rewarding days
of my life."
Mr. Berthel, who has been
director of the library since 1954,
recalls that he first met Albert

By MIKE PHILLIPS
If the varsity football team
can climax its season with a
win over Western Maryland here
tomorrow, there'll be no need
for "wait till next year." Kickoff for the alumni homecoming
clash is 2:00 P.M.
Coach Wilson Fewster's squad,
now will have only four seniors
in uniform for their final Jay
grid action. This group includes
captain Mike Oidick, George
Austin, Jeff Griffith, and Randy
Kleinert;. senior center Rip
Lhamon will not see action.
Western Maryland, holder of a
3-5 record thus far and 2-3 in
Middle Atlantic play, has not
changed its customary style of
attack much, although Ron
Jones has taken over the coaching reigns this year. The Terrors are still a ball-control team
and have the necessary stable of
good running backs to make this
type of offense go.
Prominent are two of the
team's three captains, fullback
Rick White, halfback Al Ingalls,
and 5-8 160 pound halfback
Dana Huseman, who adds good
speed to the crew. All were used
to good effect in Western Maryland's 35-12 conquest of the Jays
last year.
The Terrors are in general a
much xriore capable group than
their record would indicate,
since, with the exception of a
41.-0 pasting by Dickinson, their
losses have been by narrow margins. They lost to HampdenSydney, which routed the Homewood squad 40-0.
Dicktason made liberal use of
Jay nEtaplays last Saturday
while romping to a 48-6 victory.
Two blocked punts, several fumbles, and six intercepted passes
gave the Red Devils plenty of
scoring opportunities, and they
made ample use of them.
Although it was totally out of
the game, Hopkins didn't look
so bad in the offensive statistics,
moving for 221 total yards, 181 of
them in the air.
This passing offense was led by

Phil Parthmore, who went the
route at quarterback for the first
time in weeks. Fewster was
pleased with the junior's work
and felt that the six interceptions were a result of an inability
to hit deep receivers caused by
still-lingering arm trouble.
"It would be hard to question
the spirit or hustle of the team
last week," opined Fewster.
"Dickinson just has a fine football team which thoroughly outgunned us. They have nine of
eleven starters back from the
bunch we upset last season, and
the experience showed.
"After a bad game the week
before, Jim Cali did an outstanding job on Dickinson's top
receiver, Bob Averback," he continued, "holding him to one reception, and Bob Shannon and
Mike Shaw also did pretty well
in the secondary."
A look at the Southern Division M.A.C. and Mason-Dixon
standings reveals that the Jays
are not alone in the cellar of
either loop. Ursinus shares the
basement with Hopkins in M.A.C.
play, while Western Maryland
and Gallaudet are lumped with
the Homewood squad in M-D
action.

PeusnerTalks On Architecture
Nikolaus Pevsner, distinguished European art historian, will
deliver the Albert and Gloria
Lion Lecture at Hopkins on
Sunday, November 21 at 4 p.m.
in Shrivel. Hall. Dr. Pevsner will
speak on "The Present State of
Architecture."
The annual memorial lecture,
established by the family of Albert and Gloria Lion, alternately brings to the Baltimore community distinguished speakers
from the social sciences and the
humanities. The inaugural lecture was presented last year by
Dr. Eric Goldman, special assistant to President Lyndon B.
Johnson.
After taking a Ph.D. in the History of Art
and Architecture, Dr. Pevsner served on the
staff of the Dresden Gallery and was successively
associated with the Universities of Leipzig,
Munich, Berlin, Frankfurt and Gottingen. While
a lecturer at Gottingen, he specialized in the
history of art in Great Britain.
Dr. Pevsner now resides in Hampstead, London
and is Professor of the History of Art at Birkbeck College, University of London. He was previously Slade Professor of Fine Art and a Fellow of St. Johns' College, Cambridge.
Since its inception, Dr. Pevsner has been the
editor of the Pelican History of Art and Archilecture; he has also written some twenty-five
volumes of The Buildings of England. He is a
member of the Editorial Board of The Archi-

NIKOLAUS PlEVSNER
tectural Review and is considered among the
most learned and stimulating contemporary
writers on art.
His book on Italian Painting of Mannerism
and Baroque is held as a standard work. Among
his other publications are An Outline of European Architecture, An Inquiry into Industrial
Art in England, German Baroque Sculpture, High
Victorian Design, and The Englishness of English
Art (Reith Lectures, 1955).
The lecture is open to the public without
charge.
Further information concerning the lecture
may be obtained from George S. Wills, Office
of Public Relations, Sluiver Hall, The Johns
Hopkins University, HO '7-3300. Ext. '704, 710.

By MEL SHUSTER
Charges of discrimination were
levelled at the Hopkins administration in a report issued
Wednesday by the Hopkins Committee for Basic Freedoms. The
study, which has been distributed
to all members of the administration, faculty, and graduate
student body, deals with an alleged University discriminatory
policy in matters of housing,
employment, and admissions.
After a series of inquiries by
a number of News-Letter personnel, the position of the administration toward the report appears to be' unqualified disapproval. Some administrators refuse to comment, while some
disclaim its content. In general,
there appears to be a question
of the legitimacy of the figures
and a disapproval of the committee's procedure in making public
the report. They seem to be inclined to ignore the report rather
than respond at this time.
Housing
Beginning
with
University
housing policy, the committee's
report attacks the administration for being lax in requiring
all commerical landlords renting to Hopkins students to pledge
not to discriminate, as it had
agreed to do in 1964.
In the succeeding paragraph
of recommendations, the report
cites such housing conditions as
a major deterrent to the attendance of non-white students at
Hopkins. The committee suggests
that "A public stand by the
University on this issue would
encourage more non-white students to come here, whereas
knowledge of current housing
conditions and the general lack
of concern about them would
tend to discourage their application."

Hopkins, the committee stated
that although required to observe Equal Opportunity Employment practices because of its

Cellist Plays Jan. 9
Paul Olefsky, world renowned
American cellist, will appear in
concert at Hopkins on Sunday,
Jan. 9. The concert will be sponsored by the newly formed Hopkins chamber music group and
will feature music by the New
Chamber Orchestra under the direction of Angelo Gatto.
A review in the New York
Times noted that, "Unquestionably, Mr. Olefsky is one of the
finest cellists before\ the public
today." After winning the Naumberg Award and appearing at
Town Hall and on the Bell Telephone Hour, Olefsky became the
youngest solo cellist of the Philadelphia Orchestra. He has since
then won the Michaels Memorial

Hal Draper, an editor of New
Politics magazine and a former
member of the steering committee of the Berkley Free Speech
Movement, will speak Tuesday,
November 25, at 4 p.m. in the
Garret Room of the L.Pisenhower
Library. His topic will be "The
New Radicalism and the Future
of the Left in America."
Draper's appearance is being
sponsored by both the Hopkins
and Goucher chapters of SDS.
Questions and discussion will
follow his presentation.
One of the founders of the
Independent Socialist Club at
Berkley, Draper became wellknown to thousands of students
throughout the nation with the
publication of his pamphlet "The
Mind of Clark Kerr." In this
pamphlet, he examined the role
of the university in contemporary American society concluding that institutions of higher
education have become "factories" in which students, starting out as "raw material" are
"processed and molded" to conform to the requirements of the
roles they are expected to play
In society upon graduation.
In addition to his most recent
activities of writing and speaking about the New Left, Draper
is the former editor of Labor
Action, the newspaper of the Independent Socialist League during the late 1940's and the 1950's.
Copies of "The Mind of Clark
Kerr" and "Berkley: The New
Student Revolt," His latest book,
will be available at the speech
on Tuesday.

542 valiant Goucher students
fasted yesterday to collect money
for poor Negroes in the South.

the direction of the National
Student Association (N.S.A.) and

Student Government,

up earlier to forego their usual

Service, serving Gouc.her, will
compute the amount saved and
will turn over the money to the
N.S.A.

other states as well," stated

strenuously denied that the
project was also intended as a
mass dieting program, or as a
gambit to encourage Hopkins
students to take more Goucher
girls out to dinner.

Some Words To The Wise
We seldom generate enough conviction for an issue
to warrant warning the University administration that
their reaction to the issue if not well calculated, may have
far-reaching consequences.
The Wednesday publication on discriminatory practices at the University, submitted by the somewhat outspoken committee on Basic Freedoms is of such fundamental relevance to the policy of administration-student
relations, we are obligated to gather together, for the
administration, a few points of "student wisdom."
It is not necessarily or universally true that if one
doesn't scratch an itch, it will go away. But the officials
of the university are reluctant to admit otherwise:This
recent controversial publication is a thorn in the hide
of the administration; and we are convinced that the
best policy is not to deny any connection with the thorn,
or to privately "curse it out."
We have witnessed the truth of this, for example
by the fact that the flies who unmistakably prevail in
the Hutzler Reading Room of Gilman Hall do not respond to the shooing of them away. Nor do they respond
to the swat technique; these approaches merely add to
the persistence of their attack.
We've noticed, further of these flies, that for the
simple reason that the reading room is an inclosure
(comparable to the condition of the University as an
intellectual enclosure) a few of the flies suffocate. It
comes clear, in expanding this pertinent analogy, that
the number of the flies that do pass away are relatively
few proportional to the number who remain in force.
And it follows, consequently, that the tactic of protecting
an institutional enclosure such as the University from
discordant elements from the inside has only a limited
and often reverse effect.
Many students know, possibly because they have
been discordant elements (flies in the microcosmic
sense), that the hest way to get rid of discordant elements is to remove the cause around which they rally—
not the discordants themselves.

For the University macrocosm, this analogy says
the following things: that the four persons who have
published the report on discrimination have done so
because they honestly have discerned practices within
the University that are not compatible with their moral
convictions. Their inspiration can hardly be quelled by
silencing or by denying them official recognition. It
would be hest for concerned officials to combine efforts
with the disputants in order to discuss removal or clarification of the dispute; at any event, in order to allow
the issue to be "opened up" and the elements aired out.
We suggest, in conclusion, three steps of amelioration of this potentially explosive issue, based on policies
of inclusion rather than exclusion, of airing rather than
suffocation.
The administration should break the deadlock and
issue a report stating where they differ (in practice, not
necessarily in principle); we know of many creative attempts by the administration to attack these same issues.
The administration and the disputants might then have
grounds for conducting a public forum in which the
two groups could publically show some of the principles
they hold in common. And finally there is reason to
believe that a committee to take action on these common principles might evolve.

The old Rock and Roll—the rock and
roll of the fifties, Elvis Presley, Gene Vincent, the Platters had an appeal to a

Beatles and Bob Dylan has devleoped a
rather broad appeal. The audiences that
attend rock and roll concerts have beCome older and to a degree more sophisticated; the result of The New Rock and
Roll is an increased interest in rock and
roll among college students. Like folk music
In the early 1960's, Folk-rock or the New
Rock and Roll has become the staple
music of college students in the midsixties.
Unlike the music of the fifties most of
the New Rock and Roll is being composed
imaginatively, with greater freedom and
without the familiar cliches of the music
of the fifties. New chords, new progressions,
retrogressions and new subject matter

of Rhythm and Blues in the Early fifties—
it had its origins in the Negro and Country
music of the forties—the bebop, etc. The
first true rock and roll record recorded
by a white group was probably Crazy Man
Crazy, recorded by Bill Haley and The
Oomets,in 1951, but it was not until the

record was rereleased in 1954 that it began
to sell. In 1953, The Comets recorded Rock
Around the Clock, and this became the first

this record and the one that preceded it
were only isolated cases of rock and roll
and did not really usher in the movement.
It was a Negro group called the Chordes
that actually began the rock and roll cycle
with a recording of Sh-boom (later recorded for Mercury by the Crewcuts) in
1954. Record sales began increasing immediately in the rock field, but the first
reaction of the recording artists was to
copy the works of earlier Rhythm and
Blues singers such as Ivory Joe Tucker
and Big Bill Crudup). Emulating the style
of the earlier singers, however, the rock
and roll people began to develop their own
style—Elvis Presley, Jerry Lee Lewis, and
so on.
By 1957 it was easy to characterize most
of the rock and roll that was being recorded. The melody used the major progression (1-4-5-1), triplets were played
against a basic four-four time, and the
harmony was in triads. These predictable
elements soon tired all but the adolescent
listeners.
1958 marked the Introduction of folk
music into the rock and roll market with
the Kingston Trio's Tom Dooley. They appealed primarily to college students, sold
large numbers of albums, had a "good
act", collegiate look, and a new sound. It
seemed to be the logical refuge for the
listener tired by the familiar rock and
roll. Peter, Paul and Mary then flaunted
their image before the public, and it caught
on—among adolescent as well as the college crowds. Like the Kingston Trio, they
played much of the traditional folk music,
but soon began singing the songs Of new
song wrights—particularly Bob Dylan who
shares the same manager with Peter, Paul
and Mary (Al Grossman). Don't Think
Twice It's Alright, The Times They
Are A'Clianging and other Dylan
songs were presented to the public in a
style more readily accepted than Dylan's
own. Songs of a more contemplative mood
than normal found in the old rock and
roll were heard by the public (I parted the
weeds and looked over the swamp and
seen them natives doing the Ubangi Stomp
vs Dylans—When the rooster crows at the
break of dawn look out your window and
I'll be gone).

Honor The System
By THOMAS H. CARPENTER
Chairman,
The Honor Commission
When a freshman first arrives
at Hopkins, he is rushed through
endless orientation functions.
One of the half dozen assemblies
he attends is titled "The Honor
Assembly", and there he is told
that the Hopkins Honor System
is an important part of the undergraduate life, he is made
aware of the mechanical aspects
of the System, and he is deliberately explained his obligations under it. Then, throughout
the next four years, he is aware
of the System with each unproctored exam he takes and
with each News-Letter notification of a trial, but he is never
again reminded of his responsibilities. And although he may
graduate convinced that he has
been honorable in all of his academic pursuits, he may have only
partially fulfilled his obligations
to the preservation of the System
and with it the atmosphere of
trust and freedom from constant
observation that is so unique to
Hopkins.
Yearly, precocious freshmen
scoff at the possibility of an
Honor System and occasionally
an upper classman can be heard
to mumble that he is sure some
people cheat. Yet whether or not
the system works is wholly up
to the student body and each
student's obligation is not only

to be honorable in his academic,
pursuits, but also to turn in any
violations he may observe and
thus to protect the community
as a whole.
4 student may ask what the
phrase Honor System means,
wondering what a system of
honor can be. And the phrase
can have a pompous self-righteous air, but at Hopkins the
Honor System represents specific ideals defined through tradition. It embodies the accepted
means of pursuing academic
goals in the process of earning
a degree. Presumably the Bachelor's degree is the ultimate goal
of each student in the undergraduate body, and it is this one
factor that necessarily unites the
student body into a community
with a common purpose.
In idealistic terms, some students may be driven on by an
unquenchable thirst for knowledge, while many more are striving to be accredited in a profession and still others look for
the generally higher incomes of
Uncollege graduates.
fortunately the basis of the
structure of the degree is the
grade and again all students are
evaluated in terms of it.
The Honor System is concerned with the means a student uses
to earn his degree and thus to
earn his grades. In practical
terms, its purpose must be stated

The Johns Hopkins University
has announced the appointment
of Dr. John White, Pilkington
Professor of the History of Art
at the University of Manchester,
as Professor of Art at Homewood.
Dr. White, who will assume his
position at the beginning of the
academic year, succeeds the late
Professor Adolf Katzenellenbogen.
A specialist in early Renaissance art, Dr. White has recently
completed a volume of the Pelican History of Art, "Italian
Painting, Sculpture and Architecture, 1250-1400." He has also
published a well-known book on
the history of perspective, and is

the author of numerous articles.
As Director of the Whitworth
Gallery at the University of
Manchester, he took a strong
interest in contemporary art.
During his tenure as Director,
the collection was considerably
expanded and extensive renovations of the gallery Itself were
undertaken.
After serving as a pilot with
the R.A.F., he completed his
work for the Bachelor's degree
at Courtauld Institute of Art,
graduating in 1950 with honors.
In 1952, he was awarded a Ph.D.
by the Warburg Institute for his
thesis on "The Development of
Perspective in Renaissance Art."

• By JIM FREEDMAN
I found, in a New. Yorker of
late September, two lines of
verse, the words of an aging man
enjoying intimacy with a small
game announced on radio:
When I am told that the
hurler kicks, rocks and either
deals or delivers
I am again a tan cheeked boy
with no socks ....
Also in late September, there
was in progress the completion
of an anthology of 10 young
poets, all under 40 yrs., many of
them known well about this University, 6 of them present or
past graduate students in Elliot
Coleman's Seminar in Poetry.
Confessions and Experiments,
published by Linden Press, compiled by Robert Rosenburg, an
esteerned local poet and patron
of the arts, includes these lines
by Richard Kerschner, expressing a sentiment similar to the
above:
Shuffle through
my days and years of closets...
In an old overcoat I find
dated tickets, empty gloves:
dragon's teeth.
I remarked that the lines of
baseball remorse, by Baltimore
author Ogden Nash, pointed out,
by comparison with the lines
from Confessions and Experiments, written by a Hopkins
Senior, the value of this "September" book of poems.
These poems are young and
effectively display the diverse
pertness of youth; they are personal and intimate, as they were
chosen to be; and are very close
to home, by simple virtue of
propinquity.

While saying nothing' in particular 'about Ogden Nash, this
eoreParison.says a great deal in
favor of the .new anthology.
A Saturday Review 'article of a
few weeks passed lamented the
quality of this generation's creative writing. Its author stated
that students are "out to -picket"
rather than to conjure;'that the
distinguishing feature of the
contemporary, art form is that
it must involve both the audience
and the creator; that. as a consequence, student writing is essentially impersonal, apparently
lacking in confession and intitimacy. One critic quoted was
"depressed by how little experimentation or risk was to be
found anywhere.
We can only say, on reflection
of Confessions and Experiments,
that the Question-Title of the
Saturday Review article:. Where
Are All The Writers Gone?, can
Only be answered by saying that
the Saturday Review must have
gone with them.
The book can easily stand up
to such criticism of the age; for
its poems are, in truth, primarily
of experiments, and, without being too obvious, of confession.
"A poet writes to be believed"
is the aphorism prefacing the introduction. In this Introduction,
the editor Robert Rosenburg,
claims significantly that "poetry
is confession because it is the
most personal of all literary utterances. His claim is consistently born out by the frank expression of his chosen poets.

By HOWARD J READ

What meaning does the recent
election have for the future of
American politics? After each
election this question is asked
by those who seek to divine the
political future by analysing the.
political past. The 1965 election
was no exception to this tendency. In fact, for an "off-year"
election the results were watched
with great care by all political
attention
pundits. Particular
was focused on New York City
where the, young, liberal, and
dynamic John Lindsay was out
to win city hall for a RepublicanLiberal coalition and oust the
Democrats who had been in
power since 1945. A new twist
was present in this election, however, for a group of far-right
Republicans under the label of
the Conservative Party sought
to punish Lindsay and his supporters for departing from what
the Conservatives considered to
be genuine Republican principles.
In other parts of the country
somewhat similar things were
happening. In Philadelphia a
former Democrat was running
for District Attorney as a Republican with ADA backing. He
was seeking to be the first citywide official not elected by the
Democrats since 1948. In Louisville a liberal Republican who
had supported public accommodations legislation was seeking
approval of his actions in his
race for mayor. All three of
these areas had been completely
turned off by Barry Goldwater's
candidacy and had returned
heavy Democratic
majorities
just a year before. But in 1965,
in all three areas and in several
other similar cases the Republican candidates were successful.

Darling
If a film maker takes a pretty
thick and has her walk around
in front of the camera (with
of
changes
maybe
several
clothes), like an animated Harper's Bazaar, he's got a nice
film. If a film maker attempts to
analyze a woman's life he generally has a pretty good film.
Darling, directed by John Elsinger, is both nice and good, but
not perfect.
The film depicts the rise of a
typically-not-too-bright model to
fame and the rotten life that
greets her at the top. Each of
the elements, dramatized on the
way, is well done (with the exception of the Avant Garde party
which is the sort of thing that
never seems to come off in films),
but one has the feeling that it
would really be swell if it were
really nice when she gets to the
top. That is not the way movies
are, however, and we find that
success is really failure—in life
at least.
We watch the luscious fruits
of success fall into the fishbowl
killing the poor fish, and we see
life levy its penalties and excess
charges on Darling—while those
people about her, with all their
perversities, seem to say "its
fun."
Anyway, as the Happiness Girl
goes on trying to find happiness
her attempts become more and
more pathetic. She seems to have
found happiness in a Villa in
Capri—but only for a brief moment before she remembers her
need for AC where DC is present
but not usable. After a recharge,
she is once again thrust into her
vicious restless game — only to
become more and more unhappy.

Theatre Hopkins Presents 'Milky Way'
"Do You Know the Milky
Way?", Karl Wittlinger's tragiccomedy of the post-war German
theatre, is scheduled to be presented at the Barn December 2,
through December 5 and December 9 through December 12.
Tickets are available at the
Office of Special Events in
Sluiver Hall.
The Theatre Hopkins production, under the direction of Edward J. Golden, Jr.. will be the
play's first performance in the
Baltimore area. Since 1957, the
play has been performed more
than 7,000 times in various countries, receiving an off-Broadway
production in March 1963.
Karl Wittlinger was born in
Karlsruhe, Germany, in 1922, the
only child of a cabinetmaker.
During the War he was wounded

and held prisoner by the American Army. His first contact with
the American theatre came after
the War while working on an
American Army production of
"Our Town." Later he handled
several odd jobs while studying
for a Ph.D. in philosophy. In
1953 he decided to dedicate himself solely to the theatre.

period. The hero of his play is
a mature man who retains the
imaginatior, and innocence of a
child in a world of cruelty and
indifference. He returns after
having been cut off from the
world of reality, giving the play
its dramatic and shocking effect.

Wittlinger's third play, "Do
You Know the Milky Way?" was
originally written for twenty
characters appearing in fourteen
scenes. However, it later became
clear that he could better express
his thoughts by having his hero
face only one person, the Doctor,
who could represent all the
others in his life. By casting his
hero as a returning soldier he
was able to achieve continuity
with the German post-war

Both Arthur Lopis, as the Man,
and Irvin Turner, as the Doctor,
had roles in "The Killer" which
opened the Theatre Hopkins season. The production played to
capacity audiences and was
scheduled for extra performances.

this way. Yet the benefits that
result from the atmosphere of
trust and freedom that it allows
to exist go far beyond this superficial level. Aside from the trust
'placed in him when an instructor leaves a room during an examination, a student is often allowed to take an examination to
his room, or to take it at a
more convenient time, and this
trust spreads into innumerable
areas. Also, when a student is
suspected of violating the system, he is tried by uninvolved
peers, rather than being immediately condemned by an engaged
Instructor, and if he is found
guilty he is given a constitutionally defined penalty.
The Honor Commission is the
mechanical aspect of the System
and functions only through the
support of the community. It
does not police or search for violation.s, and the trial procedure
only comes about when a suspected violation is reported to
the Commission. The Honor
Commission uses the concept of
unfair advantage as the general
definition of an honor violation,

while in addition, an instructor
may define other specific actions
which he considers violations in
his course. The Honor Commission is not a board devised to
judge the moral fibre of an individual, nor is an individual
judged as having offended any
God-given morals. A violator of
the Honor System, found guilty
by the Commission, is found
guilty of injuring the community. He has used unacceptable
means in his academic pursuits.
These means are not defined as
acceptable or unacceptable according to any omnipotent moral
code, but rather according to
means which are defined through
tradition within the university,
degree-seeking community as
honorable. "A student's use of
unacknowledged material other
than his own" is one large aspect
of what is considered under the
phrase unfair advantage, and
this coupled with "the use of
deceit" nearly completes the definition. These very simply are
dishonorable means, not intuitively dishonorable, but defined
as dishonorable in this highly
specific community.

An applicant to the university
signs a box on his application
form, agreeing to live under the
Honor System and he is not accepted into the university unless
he signs this box. The system
cannot be partially accepted,
but the entire student body must
support it, and the penalties for
violations are directed toward
Yet a.s the
this goal.
System cannot exist without the
wholehearted support of the
community, the community as a
whole has the right to choose
whether or not to live under it.
But the choice open to the community is not whether or not to
live according to the means
established as honorable, but
rather the choice is, how these
means are to be imposed.

The Honor System is tangibly
concerned with the maintenance of the accepted structure
for attaining the Bachelor's degree, while at the same time, it
allows an atmosphere of trust
and self respect to exist. Yet the
System must not exist unless
the student body is willing to accept it and dynamically support
it without exception.

The Reading Room of the
original Gilman Hall Library
has been named in honor of the
late Mr. Albert D. Hutzler, Baltimore merchant and philantropist who served his city in the
tradition of Enoch Pratt, George
Peabody, and Johns Hopkins.
By action of the University's
Board of Trustees, the "Albert
D. Hutzler Undergraduate Reading Room" was created to honor
a University alumnus, trustee,
and past president of the Friends
of the Library.
The Hutzler Reading Room,
which serves as a focal point of
Gilman Hall, has long been
known for its scholarly atmosphere and its stained glass windows depicting the "marks" or
signatures of fifteenth century
printers.
Mr. John Berthel, University
librarian, said: "It is most appropriate that this undergraduate
facility be named for Mr. Hutzler
because he was a great friend
of Hopkins students and the
library program at the University."
Hutzler Honored
Mr. Hutzler was honored a
year ago at ceremonies opening
the new library at Hopkins,
which has subsequently been
designated the Milton S. Eisenhower Library, At that time, he
was presented with a bound volume of the "Ex Libris" periodicals published by the Friends of
the Library from 1931 to 1964.
The presentation marked one of
Mr. Hutzler's last official appearances at the University
prior to his death in June, 1965.
Mr. Hutzler's philosophy concerning the library program at
Johns Hopkins was appropriately
expressed in his remarks at the
1964 ceremonies. At that time,
he said: "It is not primarily the
building that gives us pride, it
is rather that this library will
provide vastly improved services
to the students -and faculty of
the University. It is for this reason, above all others that those
of us involved in the library's
planning found pleasure and
excitement in the work. This is
one of the most rewarding days
of my life."
Mr. Berthel, who has been
director of the library since 1954,
recalls that he first met Albert

Quarterback Jim Feely led in
total offense as the freshman
football team ground out a 2-1
record this season. A 22-6 win
over Penn Military Academy was
the finale.
Feely's net offensive total
amounted to 301 yards, all gotten
in the air. Behind him was leading ground-gainer Mark Croft,
who went 186 yards for a 4.4
Will
yard average per carry.
Scroggs netted 123 yards on the
ground (4.2), and Dan Contesti
chalked up sixty-six yards (4.11.
Scoring honors, however, went
to end John Cardillo, who also
did the squad's punting. He
caught four touchdown passes
and added six more points on
conversions. John Gorczyk had
one marker and one conversion,
and both Croft and Scroggs
scored once.
Offense Balanced
Team - statistic - wise, Hopkins
rushed for 354 yards, averaging
118 per game. With their wellbalanced attack, they did almost
as well in the air, throwing for

352 yards altogether.

their opponents' twenty-two, losing to Franklin & Marshall 8-6
and downing Western Maryland
22-8 and PMC.

Don Yablonowitz, tackles Pete
Wood and Steve Latson, and
center Phil Schroedel, Coach Bob
Scott noted the Jays' offensive
strength and remarked that in
the PMC game, Scroggs was in
on sixteen tackles.
Strong Effort

completed nine of fifteen passes
for 116 yards. Hopkins scored in
the first quarter on a thirty-two
yard pass to Cardillo and climaxed a sixty-three yard second period drive with anoaher
Feely-Cardillo touchdown.
In the fourth period Gorczyk
took a pass from Feely and went
ten yards for the score. The conversion to Cardillo was complete.
Scott generalized, "We had a
little more depth with experienced personnel this year."

By MIKE PHILLIPS
If the varsity football team
can climax its season with a
win over Western Maryland here
tomorrow, there'll be no need
for "wait till next year." Kickoff for the alumni homecoming
clash is 2:00 P.M.
Coach Wilson Fewster's squad,
now will have only four seniors
in uniform for their final Jay
grid action. This group includes
captain Mike Oidick, George
Austin, Jeff Griffith, and Randy
Kleinert;. senior center Rip
Lhamon will not see action.
Western Maryland, holder of a
3-5 record thus far and 2-3 in
Middle Atlantic play, has not
changed its customary style of
attack much, although Ron
Jones has taken over the coaching reigns this year. The Terrors are still a ball-control team
and have the necessary stable of
good running backs to make this
type of offense go.
Prominent are two of the
team's three captains, fullback
Rick White, halfback Al Ingalls,
and 5-8 160 pound halfback
Dana Huseman, who adds good
speed to the crew. All were used
to good effect in Western Maryland's 35-12 conquest of the Jays
last year.
The Terrors are in general a
much xriore capable group than
their record would indicate,
since, with the exception of a
41.-0 pasting by Dickinson, their
losses have been by narrow margins. They lost to HampdenSydney, which routed the Homewood squad 40-0.
Dicktason made liberal use of
Jay nEtaplays last Saturday
while romping to a 48-6 victory.
Two blocked punts, several fumbles, and six intercepted passes
gave the Red Devils plenty of
scoring opportunities, and they
made ample use of them.
Although it was totally out of
the game, Hopkins didn't look
so bad in the offensive statistics,
moving for 221 total yards, 181 of
them in the air.
This passing offense was led by

Phil Parthmore, who went the
route at quarterback for the first
time in weeks. Fewster was
pleased with the junior's work
and felt that the six interceptions were a result of an inability
to hit deep receivers caused by
still-lingering arm trouble.
"It would be hard to question
the spirit or hustle of the team
last week," opined Fewster.
"Dickinson just has a fine football team which thoroughly outgunned us. They have nine of
eleven starters back from the
bunch we upset last season, and
the experience showed.
"After a bad game the week
before, Jim Cali did an outstanding job on Dickinson's top
receiver, Bob Averback," he continued, "holding him to one reception, and Bob Shannon and
Mike Shaw also did pretty well
in the secondary."
A look at the Southern Division M.A.C. and Mason-Dixon
standings reveals that the Jays
are not alone in the cellar of
either loop. Ursinus shares the
basement with Hopkins in M.A.C.
play, while Western Maryland
and Gallaudet are lumped with
the Homewood squad in M-D
action.
